text.p: If [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline] are vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\langle v, w\rangle = -2[/mathjaxinline], then the matrix product [mathjaxinline]vw^ t[/mathjaxinline] is the matrix [mathjaxinline]\left[ \begin{array}{c} -2 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline].

font.p: False. [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] is a [mathjaxinline]n \times 1[/mathjaxinline] matrix, and [mathjaxinline]w^ t[/mathjaxinline] is a [mathjaxinline]1\times n[/mathjaxinline] matrix, so [mathjaxinline]vw^ t[/mathjaxinline] is an [mathjaxinline]n\times n[/mathjaxinline] matrix. To get [mathjaxinline]\left[ \begin{array}{c} -2 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], we would need to take [mathjaxinline]w^ tv[/mathjaxinline] or [mathjaxinline]v^ tw[/mathjaxinline] (both would give the same result; note that [mathjaxinline]\langle v,w\rangle = \langle w, v\rangle[/mathjaxinline]).
